main.title: High school
main.content: Apart from 2nd grade math class, my interest in technical subjects and IT started at the Secondary School of Electrical Engineering in Pardubice (SPŠE), where I studied Communication Technology. It was here where I first encountered programming, mostly with the backend (Java) and microprocessor technology (Arduino), but also a bit with the front-end, i.e. creating websites and web applications.

main.title: University
main.content: For my further studies, I decided to study at UHK, FIM faculty, field of study Information Management. I am currently studying for a Bachelor's degree and I plan to continue my Master's degree in the same field. Here I also approached programming (html, css, javascript, java, and database work). The knowledge I gained from the mandatory classes wasn't quite enough, so I started learning on my own in my free time.

main.title: Selfeducation
main.content: First I wanted to learn about the backend because I was interested in how it all works, so I spent a year learning Python. After that, I wanted to at least get some knowledge of the front-end and learn full-stack, but I ended up staying with the front-end and I've been trying to get better at it for the last year. Primarily I'm trying to improve in react/next and write good quality readable code.

main.title: HTML5, CSS3 & Sass
main.content: I was introduced to HTML and CSS in elementary school and today I am familiar with both. Lately, I have not encountered pure HTML or CSS. I write HTML through JSX in React and use the scss/sass preprocessor rather than plain CSS. All three programming related courses have included both HTML and CSS, from the basics to advanced functions.

main.title: Javascript
main.content: Javascript is another of the basics for me, although I didn't encounter it until the end of high school/beginning of college. I learned javascript in both of my front-end focused courses, so I know and understand the language itself. I was probably too quick to get into the framework (React), and therefore I'm still learning some javascript principles as I go along.

main.title: React
main.content: Deciding between the React and Angular frameworks was a bit more difficult for me, but in the end, I chose React and in retrospect, it seems like a great choice. I first encountered React in my first FrontEnd course and before I finished it completely I took a course specialized in React, Redux and Typescript, which I'm still finishing because now I'm spending my time more on real projects.

main.title: Next.js
main.content: Next.js wasn't such a clear choice for me mainly because of Pages router, which I don't like nearly as much as the relatively new App router, but once it went live and is no longer in 'test version' I started using only Next and would like to continue using it, though of course, I have no problem learning another framework.

main.title: Git & GitHub
main.content: Git and GitHub are definitely the basics for me, and I tend to work with Control Version on a daily basis, always having every code commit active on GitHub. I know that every company works with GitHub, so I consider this skill to be essential. I've had Git and GitHub in all three of my courses and I encounter it in every project and video I learn from.

main.title: Python
main.content: I initially saw python as my future as a programmer, but after learning more about the front-end, I was more interested in doing something more visible. I still liked Python a lot and I took the entire 100 day course on Udemy, which took me almost a year. The course took me from playing hangman, through working with libraries (NumPy, Matplotlib, SciPy, etc), all the way to the basics of AI.
